title: How to guarantee that if I buy a house with my boyfriend, if he dies before me, his kids won't force me out for their half of the equity - Quora

response.answer_text: Well… don’t. If he specifies you to inherit the house in his will, that would solve the issue… but the will can be changed or challenged. Otherwise (and per a response you made to another answer) you almost certainly wind up owning half the house, with his kids owning the other half. That’s a difficult situation… unlikely they could legally force you out, but how would you collect an equitable portion of the cost of maintaining the house? Taxes? Sounds like one battle after another. They could effectively force you to pay all the costs of the housing by simply refusing to pay. Even if you move out you’d have come to an agreement of how to sell it (or a price on them buying from you.) Plenty of ways for this to get ugly, and few ways for it to go well and fairly. So we’re back to: don’t do it. The only way this works as desired is marriage (and that still doesn’t actually accomplish his goal of making sure his kids get an inheritance, which is a very reasonable thing.) If you don’t have a relationship where you are comfortable getting married, then you surely shouldn’t enter into a life altering financial commitment with the guy. Heck, you could very likely run into the same issues of who pays what bills and/or when to sell with the boyfriend, and if you break up you now have to deal with the same issues as above. Thinking out of the box: this isn’t really about equity, it’s about money. He could buy a life insurance policy with at the same time as buying the house with the kids as the beneficiaries. That way the kids get a similar cash payment without the baggage of a house. Or, you could be the beneficiary with the kids getting the house. If you got a check for the full value of the house (plus some, ideally) that would allow you to get a new place, potentially mortgage free. Of course, the beneficiaries or the will can be changed also, so…

How do I guarantee that if I buy a house with my boyfriend, if he dies before me, his kids won't force me out for their half of the equity? My son is special needs and I don't want to ever have to worry about losing my house or being forced out. What if you die before your boyfriend? What would happen to your child? You see, your situation is more complicated than you think. If you were childless, then I’d suggest you that you and your boyfriend own the house in some form of joint tenancy with a right of survivorship. With that kind of ownership, if one of you died, the other would automatically own the entire house; his kids couldn’t do anything to force you out. BUT you do have a child. If you died first, your boyfriend would get everything and your son would get nothing. So joint ownership with a right of survivorship won’t work. Plus, he probably wants to give his own children his share of the house. The two of you need to talk about what each of you wants, needs, and expects, then learn what options you have under your local laws to achieve those. I suggest you spend a few hundred dollars to discuss your situation with a local lawyer who has experience in your local property and inheritance law. Protecting your son is extremely important. Don’t make the mistake of “saving” money now and losing a lot more later.

Laws vary from state to state. I am trying to recall the exact wording on the title to a house I had with my mother. It was something like title is transferred to “me and her as tenants in joint with the right of survivorship”. Then get a term life insurance policy in the value of half the house with his kids as beneficiaries. That way you would get the house and they would get the value of his half. It seems to me that you both could live a long life yet and if you are working and paying half the mortgage then, particularly with your situation it would be better if you got the house when and if he ever dies. If he is the only one working then a second term life insurance policy that would pay off the house might also be a good idea. This could also likely be included as part of the mortgage but that might be more expensive.

You haven't bothered to tell us what country or jurisdiction you're in, so nobody can give you a useful answer unless they guess right. Ensure that the lawyer sets up the deed so that it's taken care of. In Ontario that would be called Joint Tenancy and the surviving owner would inherit the decedent's interest in the property. Of course you'll have to ensure that you and he are on the same page before you start looking for a house. You need to have a solid agreement based on a clear understanding of the legal implications.

It is easy Just add to the deed that both you and your son would always have the right to live there rent free until you specifically give up that right Who would buy a house with such a clause? And even if someone does buy it They still have to honor that clause and let you and your son live there rent free for as long as you wish

There are important differences between the laws of England and Wales, and those in Scotland. Please specify the country in which the property is located. Anyway, in England and Wales when you buy the house jointly you can choose whether to own it as what are called Joint Tenants, or alternatively Tenants in Common. Depending on your choice, either (i) the whole house belongs equally to both of you, so that if one of you dies the entire house becomes exclusively the property of the remaining person; or (ii) each of you owns half the house, so if one person dies that person’s share becomes part of the estate and may be claimed by any heirs. Be aware that English law may not apply in some remote parts of the world.

Depending on the jurisdiction and estate laws, you will need to ensure your both on the deed to the house, are listed as co-owners with equal rights to the property in tax records, that the house is noted as transferring to the surviving spouse/partner upon death. Because estate and related laws vary it’s important to consult with a lawyer who specializes in estate planning and related laws. The time and investment you make now will save you a lot of grief later.

I’d consider life insurance with you as the beneficiary and an amount that would be enough to buy out his half of the house from his heirs. I assume you already have a policy on yourself to cover your son’s needs if you die. But, off the top of my head I’d guess the odds are better that you’ll split up first which leaves an equally sticky problem.

In the US, a title with joint survivorship means the survivor gets the house. However, you state you have a special needs child. I highly recommend consulting a lawyer on how to provide for your son when you die. Comingling your assets with your boyfriend may leave your son destitute if you were to die before the boyfriend.

Do not take this advice on Quora. Talk to an estate lawyer. This is easy to do and fairly cheap. Do NOT enter into this transaction without talking to a lawyer first. My reaction is that an estate trust would settle this but you must talk to a lawyer, way too much bad advice here.

Since you are not married, if you buy the house together, buy it as a TENANCY IN COMMON. This is the format business partners choose. Each partner may have different % interests. Unless they buy you out, they can't kick you out. Caveat: it works in reverse too. In contrast, JOINT TENANCY is reserved for husband/wife, and you don't fit that category.
Warranty deed. Joint tenancy with rights of survivorship. That means when one owner dies, full ownership goes to the remaining owners listed on the deed. Automatic. No probate. Non contestable.
title the house as joint with rights of servivorship. if you die he gets your half. if he dies you get his half. or you 2 can just title the house in your sons name.
You need to have a written, recordable agreement about the house, which you should have an attorney prepare before you buy the house.
You can’t. Marriage is the only thing that will give you a legal leg up on his children.
Talk to a lawyer. Maybe his will can have a right of occupancy clause where they can’t toss you out.
You can’t. You are playing house and that comes with risk. You don’t have the protection that a marriage license would give.
I am not a lawyer nor is this legal advise.. This would be done by both names being done on the title and specified on his will.
